some note:
- rukkhadevas have a meeting every fortnight to remind each other not to break the rukkhadhamma which is not to have anger when others cut their trees causing the disappearance of their mansions otherwise they are not accepted in the deva assemblies and may be reborn in apāya.
-  the mansion was buddhadeyya,  so no one could come to occupied.

5 types of bīja:
1. mūla: root
2. khanda: stem
3. phalu: joints
4. agga: bud
5. bīja: seed
Bhūtagāma: is grown from these 5 types of bīja
if  it is still able to propagate, so it is called bhūtagāma.
separated part of bhūtagāma, if it is possible to propagate, it  is bījagāma.
stump that potential to grow, it is still call bhūtagāma, but such stump like coconut it is bīja.
![[bhūtagama_Drawing 2024-01-16 09.52.54.excalidraw]]

aquatic plant after removed from water,  it became  bījagāma.
algae should not taken out  without water.

piyañgu

panasa (jack tree)
### Pañca Samaṇa Kappa (Vohāra)
>Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, pañcahi samaṇakappehi phalaṃ paribhuñjituṃ, aggiparicitaṃ, satthaparicitaṃ, nakhaparicitaṃ, abījaṃ, nibbaṭṭabījaññeva pañcamaṃ. Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, imehi pañcahi samaṇakappehi phalaṃ paribhuñjituṃ.

pañca samaṇakappa/ samaṇa-vohāra:
1. Aggiparicitaṃ (parijita) – fruit burnt by fire
2. satthaparicitaṃ (satthaparijita) – fruit cut by a weapon
3. nakhaparicitaṃ (nakhaparijita) – fruit cut by nail
4. Abīja – fruit that has no seed
5. nibbaṭṭabīja – fruit that has its seed extracted

### Kappiya Karaṇa (Making Bījagāma Allowable)
As Sāratthadīpanī states, an anupasampanna must do the kappiya karaṇa only after the monk has said “kappiyaṃ karohi”. The anupasampanna must burn, cut or pierce the bījagāma having said the word “kappiyaṃ”. **If the anupasampanna says “kappiyaṃ” having burnt, cut or pierced the bījagāma, the source of vegetation is not made allowable**. Some teachers are of the opinion that it is fine if the anupasampanna puts the bījagāma into fire and says “kappiyaṃ” or cut (or pierce) it with a weapon (or nail) and says “kappiyaṃ” without lifting the weapon. It is also mentioned that some teachers are of the opinion, that the word kappiya could be said in any language.

$monk-\frac{bhūtagāma}{destroyed}>bhūtagāma=>P$
$monk-\frac{doubt}{destroyed}>bhūtagāma=>D$
$monk-\frac{abhūtagāma}{destroyed}>bhūtagāma=>None$

$monk-\frac{bhūtagāma}{destroyed}>abhūtagāma=>D$
$monk-\frac{doubt}{destroyed}>abhūtagāma=>D$
$monk-\frac{abhūtagāma}{destroyed}>abhūtagāma=>None$
---
$monk-\frac{bījagāma}{destroyed}>bījagāma=>P$
$monk-\frac{doubt}{destroyed}>bījagāma=>D$
$monk-\frac{aabījagāma}{destroyed}>bījagāma=>None$

$monk-\frac{abījagāma}{destroyed}>abījagāma=>D$
$monk-\frac{doubt}{destroyed}>abījagāma=>D$
$monk-\frac{abījagāma}{destroyed}>abījagāma=>None$
catu-dukkaṭa. extra for bīja

**sacittaka, saññāvimokkha offence.** 
**ekaka-pācittiya and tika-dukkaṭa offence**

### Non-offences
1. If a monk destroys or gets someone else to destroy a bhūtagāma with abīja-saññā, he will not commit any offence.
2. There is no offence for destroying a thing that is not a bhūtagāma with abīja-saññā.
3. If a bhikkhu uses appropriate language (kappiya vohāra) such as: “Know this, give this, bring it here, this is useful, make this allowable”, an offence will not be committed.
Further, if stated, “Cut the trees, pluck the flowers etc.” **without specifying a certain bhūtagāma** or many bhūtagāmas, an offence will not occur.

> if 1 person is stuck with creepers, others can come and break the tree to save fellow monks. but not himself.

4. **Asañcicca**: For ones who happen to destroy bhūtagāma without thinking “I shall break this” etc., there will be no offence. If grass is destroyed when trees or stones are rolled over or when a branch is dragged or when the earth is prodded while using a walking stick, it is considered an act that is conducted without thinking of destroying bhūtagāma because there was no thought of deliberate destruction. Therefore, if destroyed this way without thinking, such monks will not be committing an offence.
5. **Asatiyā**: For those who do while the mind is else where there will be no offence. “Asatiya chindati” means a monk while speaking to someone plucks grass or a vine using toenails or hands without being aware that he is doing so. In such a scenario, an offence will not entail as the destruction takes place while his mind was elsewhere.
6. **Ajānantassa**: For those who do not know (ajānantassa) there will be no offence. That is not knowing that something is bījagāma or bhūtagāma, and not knowing that it is being destroyed. If one keeps a spade or any other weapon within a patch of grown grass for protection or drops a fire torch to the ground when the flame begins to burn the hands, and if such acts destroy the grass or burns it, an offence will not occur.
7. **Paṭaggidāna**: The Buddha has allowed monks to give a back fire burring the trees when a wildfire is approaching – “Anujānāmi, bhikkhave, davaḍāhe ḍayihamāne paṭaggi dātuṃ”.
